author: Maarten Mittner
title: JSE closes 0.50% firmer, despite big sell-off of golds and platinums | Markets
text:
Picture: MICHAEL ETTERSHANK Related articles Gold and platinum equities buckle under weak metal prices Bonds steady at weaker levels Rand softer as dollar strength weighs on commodity prices THE JSE all share closed higher on Monday despite a massive sell-off in gold and platinum shares after the gold price fell to a five-year low.
The gold index lost more than 10% at one point and closed at levels last seen 15 years ago in 2000.
The greenback was at a three-month best level on Monday after US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen’s comments last week that a US interest rate hike would probably materialise this year. Firmer US economic data on Friday also underpinned the dollar with the strong dollar weighing heavily on commodity prices.
At the JSE’s close the gold price was 2.48% lower at $1,105.79 per ounce and the platinum price had dropped 1.10% to $983/oz.
Barclays Research said in a note European equities were higher after German Chancellor Angela Merkel held out the prospect of limited debt relief as banks in Greece reopened on Monday, three weeks after they were shut, although capital controls and limits on withdrawals remain in place.
"Markets had been resilient with an abrupt turn in risk sentiment in equities despite the Greece– and China–induced volatility," Barclays said.
Despite the sell-off in gold and platinum stocks on the JSE, there was a relatively buoyant interest in industrial and financial shares, cushioning the bourse and enabling the all share index to close firmer.
The Dow opened flat at the JSE’s close and the FTSE 100 was 0.06% higher as the Paris CAC 40 gained 0.23%. The German Dax was 0.48% higher.
At 5pm the all share was 0.50% higher at 52,988.30 and the blue chip top 40 had gained 0.71%. The gold index closed 9.53% lower and the platinum index was down 3.87%. Resources shed 0.93%. Industrials firmed 0.83% and banks gained 0.50%. Financials added 0.46%.
Stanlib retail investing director Paul Hansen said commodity prices have been sliding as global equity markets lifted last week. The Economist Metals Index was down 12.6% in dollars so far this year, and at a five-year low, and -43% down from its peak in 2011. Iron ore, copper, aluminium, nickle and zinc prices also continue to fall.
"Obviously the strong dollar is hurting commodity prices, as gold and platinum prices slide even further, but there are also concerns about the slowing Chinese economy," he said.
There is a lower need for metals in China’s infrastructure development, because China accounts for almost 50% of the world’s refined metal consumption.
"This is giving way to a more consumer and service oriented economy, that needs less metals," Mr Hansen said.
Among individual global mining house stocks South32 (S32) was 1.09% lower at R16.32. Anglo American managed to pare some of its earlier losses, but still closed 0.26% off at R168.06. BHP Billiton added 0.59% to R239.92.
Kumba Iron Ore closed 3.94% lower at R122.57 and Assore lost 3.06% to R87.25.
Naspers lifted 1.48% to R1,925.00.
Local gold producer Sibanye led the gold stocks lower, shedding 10.62% to R17.50, its lowest level in 18 months. AngloGold Ashanti was 9.70% weaker at R85.34 and Gold Fields lost 9.32% to R34.35. Harmony was off 9.16% at R12.50.
Among platinum stocks Lonmin dropped 4.84% to R14.75 and Anglo American Platinum shed 3.54% to R259.49. Impala Platinum was 3.19% lower at R48.89.
Among banks Capitec added 2.78% to R464 and among financials Discovery lifted 1.14% to R140.59.
Retailer The Foschini Group closed 2.53% higher at R155.
Property stocks were mixed on lower bond yields as Growthpoint eased 0.86% to R27.70 but Octodec added 4.44% to R26.11.
Curro Holdings closed 2.11% higher at R34.80.
Brait closed 2.71% higher at R138.50.
